Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Signal processing for enabling high speed probe based nanoimaging

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
A key enabler of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology is the Atomic Force Microscope (AFM) that has opened up new realms, of interrogation and manipulation of matter at the atomic scale. It has resulted in breakthroughs in understanding sub-atomic molecular structure, protein folding dynamics and materials characterization. The potential impact of significantly faster AFM based imaging is immense, e.g., it will allow the study of dynamics of material at the nanoscale that was hitherto not accessible. The aim of this research is to study modern signal processing techniques that achieve gains in imaging speeds by an order of magnitude. The investigators will push the synergistic transfer of knowhow between the engineering and the AFM communities through student visits and specialized workshops. The findings will be integrated at appropriate levels into the undergraduate and graduate curriculum.

The main component of an AFM is a cantilever that deflects in response to forces at the pico-Newton scale. The focus of this research is the dynamic mode AFM operation, where the cantilever gently taps the sample being imaged; the mode of choice for imaging biological samples. Even though forces do form a good indicator of sample topography, the system memory and the nonlinearities of the AFM system dynamics preclude a direct mapping of the cantilever forces into a finer description of topography, especially at high imaging speeds. The investigators model the complex nanoscale interactions in a mathematically tractable manner that facilitates the development of maximum a posteriori (MAP) sequence detection of the sample features. Factor graph representations and the development of appropriate inference schemes will be studied. The algorithms will be implemented on FPGAs and tested exhaustively with experimental data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The atomic force microscope is technology that has had a significant impact on the basic sciences. It allows scientists in various domains to image matter at the atomic scale and has led to several insights and discoveries. The AFM employs a cantilever with a sharp tip that deflects based on atomic level forces. Imaging is performed by appropriately interpreting this deflection signal.

In this project, the overall goal was to improve the speed and fidelity of dynamic mode AFM imaging by using techniques from signal processing. The following main contributions were made in our work.

We demonstrated that the cantilever in dynamic mode can be viewed as an appropriate linear and time invariant system. The properties of these systems have been well studied in the signal processing literature. Following this, we proposed a fast method for detecting the presence or absence of topographic feature in a sample. The main idea was to design two observers that are matched to different modes in which the cantilever can possibly be. For example, if the cantilever is interacting with the sample, the corresponding observer can track the motion of the cantilever with small error. In this way, the tracking error signals were leveraged for performing feature detection. The performance of this detection technique is significantly faster and higher fidelity than competing methods.

In the second contribution, we focused on the problem which is of great interest in material science. Each material exhibits a certain force profile when interacting with the cantilever. Essentially, this is a plot of the force experienced by the cantilever as a function of the tip-material separation. Conventional techniques for measuring the force curve of a specific material are rather slow since they require the cantilever to settle down into a steady state trajectory. In our work we propose fast technique that works in the time-domain. Our method can recover the force curve even when the cantilever is in the transient mode. It has the potential to allow for real time measurement of force curves.

The project allowed for the training of several graduate students and prepared them for a career in the workforce.
